statement.p: An aircraft in flight has total energy given by \displaystyle\frac{{1}}{{2}}{m}{v}^{{2}}+{m}{g}{h} where
\displaystyle{m} is the mass of the aircraft in pounds
\displaystyle{h} is the height above sea level in feet
Suppose a glider with mass 1072 lbs and initial velocity 99 ft/s is at an altitude of 3,700. ft MSL. If the glider forces a descent to 3,526 ft MSL, what must the new velocity be? ft/s
Altitudes have four significant digits. Hint: The total energy will be the same before and after the altitude change.
